author: By Victor Mather
title: Video Shows Officer Repeatedly Punching Woman Held on Ground
description: The Charlotte, N.C., police, which opened an internal investigation, said the woman had struck an officer and resisted arrest.
content: The police in Charlotte, N.C., have started an internal investigation after a video was shared on social media showing an officer repeatedly punching a woman while other officers restrained her on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Stuntman Paralyzed While Making ‘Harry Potter’ Tells His Story
description: In a new documentary, David Holmes, a stunt performer in the ‘Harry Potter’ films, recalls his life before and after a harrowing accident on set that left him paralyzed.
content: When David Holmes arrived at rehearsal to perfect a fight scene for the penultimate “Harry Potter” film, he was strapped into a harness that was supposed to send him flying backward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: He Thought His Chuck Close Painting Was Worth $10 Million. Not Quite.
description: A bittersweet ending for Mark Herman, the dog walker who was given the painting: It finally sold, but for far less than he had envisioned.
content: Have you ever had this fantasy? You befriend a curmudgeonly stranger and one day, out of the blue, the old grouch bequeaths you a gift to change your life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.8 Million Homes in New York, Tennessee and Colorado
description: A modern retreat in Tivoli, a late 19th-century Shingle Style house in Signal Mountain and an 1891 limestone home in Denver.
content: This house is about 10 minutes from the center of Tivoli, a Hudson Valley village with a bakery, an Irish-style pub and boutiques selling a number of things, including yarn and locally made housewares. It is also about 10 minutes from the village of Red Hook, which has a diner in a vintage train car and a public high school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Waiting for Godot’ Review: Old Friends Falling in and Out of Sync
description: Michael Shannon and Paul Sparks star in Arin Arbus’s pandemic-delayed production at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center.
content: Samuel Beckett left as little as possible to chance when he wrote “Waiting for Godot,” a play that, 70 years after its first production, usually looks substantially the same: the country road, the withered tree, the battered boots arranged at the top of Act II with “heels together, toes splayed.” In his stage directions, Beckett spent 195 words choreographing some horseplay involving hats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Hate That Doesn’t Know Its Own Name
description: “You can be a Ph.D. and an S.O.B. at the same time,” says the U.S. envoy for combating antisemitism.
content: When the historian Deborah Lipstadt defeated a libel suit brought against her in a British court by the Holocaust denier David Irving in April 2000, it was almost possible to imagine that antisemitism might someday become a thing of the past, at least in much of the West. Taking a trip to Israel was not an ideologically fraught choice. Wearing a Star of David was not a personally risky one. College campuses did not feel hostile to Jewish students. Synagogues (at least in the United States) did not have police officers stationed outside their doors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Dreyer
title: A Message for the Aging Men Steering U.S.-China Relations
description: America and China are talking again. For the sake of our planet, let’s keep it that way.
content: A couple of weeks ago, a young crowd in Shanghai came out in force to celebrate Halloween. The street where I live filled with revelers dressed in a range of elaborate costumes — as the white-clad enforcers of China’s Covid lockdowns, as Chinese courtesans or simply as a watermelon. Halloween allows us to dress up as something that we can’t otherwise be. It’s a strong impulse right now in China, which remains stuck in a postpandemic malaise marked by job shortages, a trend of disillusioned 20-somethings dropping out of the work force and society and a general yearning for a different way to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Katie Rogers
title: Biden-Xi Talks Lead to Little but a Promise to Keep Talking
description: Both American and Chinese accounts of the meeting indicated scant progress on the issues that have pushed the two nations to the edge of conflict.
content: President Biden said on Wednesday that four hours of discussion with President Xi Jinping of China had brought about two significant agreements, on curbing fentanyl production and on military-to-military communications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: U.S. and China Agree to Displace Fossil Fuels by Ramping Up Renewables
description: The climate agreement between the two countries is seen as a bright spot as President Biden prepares to meet President Xi Jinping.
content: The United States and China, the world’s two largest climate polluters, have agreed to jointly tackle global warming by ramping up wind, solar and other renewable energy with the goal of displacing fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Hans Buetow, Reva Goldberg, Jen Poyant, Anabel Bacon, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Carole Sabouraud and Pat McCusker
title: He Cared About Me, So I Broke Up With Him
description: For years, Jessica Slice had dumped any guy who was kind to her. Could she break the cycle?
content: When Jessica Slice started dating a man named David, there was a lot to like about him. They could nerd out about books and board games. He was thoughtful and kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Battle for U.S. House Control in 2024 Is Fought in a New York Courtroom
description: The state’s highest court, which struck down Democrats’ gerrymandered map in 2022, is considering whether to let them try to redraw district lines again.
content: The fight over one of the most consequential congressional battlegrounds in the nation took center stage on Wednesday — not in the hotly contested suburbs or a campaign convention hall, but in a staid courtroom in Buffalo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Woman Killed in Belgium 31 Years Ago Is Identified by Her Flower Tattoo
description: Interpol began an effort this spring to identify 22 women who had been found dead over the years, leading to more than 1,000 tips. Now, one woman has a name.
content: A British woman who was killed in Belgium 31 years ago was identified this week thanks to an international campaign that began earlier this year to identify nearly two dozen women who were found dead across Europe, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes’ Review: Fallen Snow
description: This slow-burning prequel tells the origin story of Coriolanus Snow, the future president of Panem.
content: The 18-year-old Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth) — future president of Panem, eventual tormentor of Katniss Everdeen — begins “The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes” with his stomach growling. This slow-burning prequel by the franchise’s returning director Francis Lawrence rewinds six and a half decades in the life of the despot (played in the other films by Donald Sutherland) to find young Snow tinkering with the 10th Hunger Games, a rinky-dink massacre hosted by a weatherman (Jason Schwartzman). (Katniss would suffer the 74th.) Only its designer (Viola Davis) sees the potential in developing a Grand Guignol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Chiseled Cheekbones and Comic Chops: Why We Don’t Like Our Stand-Ups Hunky
description: Can good-looking guys be funny? The conventional wisdom is that men in comedy need to come across as relatable, not hot. But that may be changing.
content: My first thought upon seeing the stand-up comic Matt Rife, before knowing much of anything about him, was that I didn’t like him. This wasn’t a considered opinion, so much as a knee-jerk prejudice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Jimmy Kimmel Said to Be Returning as Oscars Host
description: It will be the late-night comedian’s fourth time as M.C. of the awards ceremony, which won back some viewers last year.
content: Academy Awards organizers have decided to stick with a tried and true host: Jimmy Kimmel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: Kevin Hart to Receive Mark Twain Prize for American Humor
description: The comedian and movie star will get the honor, the most prestigious in comedy, at a March ceremony.
content: In his rise to the very top of the comedy world, Kevin Hart has done everything from delivering hit specials to selling out a football stadium to starring in box office smashes like “Jumanji.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart and Benjamin Mullin
title: Behind CNN Turmoil, a Series of Shattered Friendships
description: David Zaslav, the chief executive of Warner Bros. Discovery, was friends with some of the network’s biggest names. That didn’t matter when their jobs were on the line.
content: When Chris Licht faced criticism for his management of CNN, from both inside the newsroom and beyond, he had every reason to believe that his close personal relationship with David Zaslav, the chief executive of the network’s parent company, would protect him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Alex Stern, Will Reid, Carlos Prieto, Stella Tan, John Ketchum, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: A Strategy to Treat Big Tech Like Big Tobacco
description: More than three dozen states have come together in a lawsuit against Meta, the company behind Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
content: A historic set of new lawsuits, filed by more than three dozen states, accuses Meta, the country’s largest social media company, of illegally luring children onto its platforms and hooking them on its products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Amazon to Stop Selling Seven Eyedrops After F.D.A. Warning
description: The Food and Drug Administration told the online retailer in a letter this week that the products were not approved for sale in the United States.
content: Amazon said on Wednesday that it was removing seven eyedrops products from its website after the Food and Drug Administration warned the company that the eyedrops had not been recognized as safe and effective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen and Vishakha Darbha
title: News Organizations Should Publish This Photo
description: How one image captures the human toll of war in Gaza.
content: The scenes of devastation from Gaza are widespread on social media, but mainstream news organizations, including The New York Times, often have a directive to not publish overly graphic photographs. In this audio essay, the Opinion columnist Lydia Polgreen argues that there are times when we should not look away — and that it is our moral obligation to bear witness to images of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: ‘Scott Pilgrim’ Is Back, Now in Anime Form
description: “Scott Pilgrim Takes Off” revives the bassist who battles his romantic rivals. In an interview, the creators discuss the next chapter, for Netflix.
content: Let’s get ready to rumble … again! Friday brings the premiere of “Scott Pilgrim Takes Off,” an anime series based on the comic book about a young, lollygagging amateur bass player battling seven of his new love’s exes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Larissa Anderson and Sophia Lanman
title: Pomegranate Molasses Is a Star of the Pantry
description: In the pantry with Melissa Clark.
content: In this series, Melissa Clark takes you inside her pantry to talk about how best to use the ingredients stocked there. Today: the perfect balance of tartness and sweetness that is pomegranate molasses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Top German Journalist Received Payments From Putin Ally, Leak Reveals
description: The revelation that the broadcaster Hubert Seipel received hundreds of thousands of euros from an oligarch is stirring worries in Germany that Russia is using an old playbook to promote its interests.
content: After Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Germany went through a period of uncomfortable soul-searching about the close ties that some of its political and business leaders had to Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Jennifer Aniston and Other ‘Friends’ Actors Reminisce After Matthew Perry’s Death
description: Lisa Kudrow and Matt LeBlanc were among the cast members who shared Instagram posts with their memories of Perry, who died in October.
content: Cast members of “Friends,” who shared coffee and apartments in their roles on the long-running series, reminisced in Instagram posts this week about the scenes they shared with Matthew Perry, who played Chandler Bing on the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Happy Newish Year!
description: On TikTok, 2024 starts … now.
content: There are six weeks left in 2023, but some people on social media are already popping the champagne, yelling “Happy New Year!” and jump-starting their resolutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Everybody Is a Bit on Edge’: Sailors Trade Tips on Steering Clear of Orcas
description: With a pod of the sea creatures ramming boats in the Strait of Gibraltar, some crews are turning to homegrown solutions. Can playing heavy metal really keep them away?
content: The first time orcas appeared near his catamaran, Florian Rutsch was surprised, but prepared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Do Women’s Sports Deserve More Attention?
description: Coco Gauff. Simone Biles. Caitlin Clark. A columnist says we are witnessing the rise of female athletes. Do you agree?
content: Last month, an exhibition game at Kinnick Stadium at the University of Iowa between the Iowa and DePaul women’s basketball teams attracted 55,646 fans — a record crowd to watch a women’s basketball game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: One of the World’s Greatest Shoppers Prepares to Share Her Treasures
description: Mouna Ayoub has a huge collection of haute couture, and now, 252 of her Chanel pieces designed by Karl Lagerfeld are going up for auction.
content: Once upon a time — 1976, in fact — a beautiful, poor 18-year-old Lebanese waitress named Mouna Ayoub was cleaning tables in Paris. She caught the eye of an older man, a billionaire from Saudi Arabia. They married, and he soon whisked her away from France to a life of gilded splendor in the desert kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Pop-Tart Critic
description: If you could be a taste tester for any food in the world, what would it be and why?
content: “Almost every family has a secret they never discuss,” writes Laura M. Holson in a recent essay for the Food section. “Ours is this: We were taste testers for Pop-Tarts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Israeli Troops Enter Gaza Hospital, and More
description: Plus, Biden and Xi Jinping prepare to meet and the House passes a plan to avoid a shutdown.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walt Bogdanich, Isak Hüllert and Eli Tan
title: So Thieves Nabbed Your Catalytic Converter. Here’s Where It Ended Up.
description: The pollution control devices contain valuable metals, making them a hot commodity for recycling. Some beneficiaries of the thefts look the other way.
content: One morning in September, a truck disgorged its load of pulverized rock with a resounding bang inside Stillwater Mining’s metallurgical plant north of Yellowstone National Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Sends Biden Stopgap Funding Bill, Averting a Government Shutdown
description: But Republican hard-liners rebelled again in the House, underscoring serious difficulties ahead for a long-term federal funding deal.
content: Congress gave final approval on Wednesday to a bill to fund federal agencies into early next year, averting an immediate shutdown crisis but leaving the path toward a longer-term agreement on government spending as rocky as ever.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Freeway Closed? Drivers in L.A. Don’t Sweat It.
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 15, 2023.
content: “That’s the L.A. mind-set: If it’s inconvenient for me and if it’s going to be difficult to get there, I’d rather just not go.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: A Really Great Polenta Finishes Off Strong
description: Infused oil gives a final kick to this dish with roasted-until-golden mushrooms and charred tomatoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: ordeal
description: This word has appeared in 291 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word ordeal has appeared in 291 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 31 in “I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life” by Erik Vance:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Calls Tumultuous Senate Hearing ‘U.F.C.-SPAN’
description: Late night hosts couldn’t resist joking about Senator Markwayne Mullin challenging the Teamsters leader Sean M. O’Brien to a brawl.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: ‘How to Dance in Ohio’: A Story About Autism and Connection
description: In a first for Broadway, openly autistic actors are playing the autistic characters in this new musical about a doctor helping neurodiverse clients.
content: To get to Amigo Family Counseling, I walked down beige hallways on the first floor of a building in a ho-hum Columbus, Ohio, office park a short walk from a Bob Evans restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Cost of Streaming
description: Hollywood is simultaneously booming and suffering.
content: Streaming technology has allowed people to spend much more time watching entertainment than they did in the past. They can binge entire shows if they enjoy the first episode. They can watch almost any movie on an airplane flight or a subway ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A Reporter Was Ready for a Sickle Cell Breakthrough
description: Gene therapy offers hope to patients in dire need of treatment. Gina Kolata has met several of them.
content: It’s a classic puzzle presented to genetics students. How can a disease that often kills people before reproductive age — a disease like sickle cell — persist in a population?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: We No Longer Need a Big Carrier’s Wireless Plan. Discount Ones Are the Way.
description: We are overpaying for phone plans from Verizon, AT&T and T-Mobile. Budget wireless services, similarly fast and robust, can save thousands.
content: Americans have long been conditioned to believe that when they buy a cellphone, the next step is to pick a wireless plan from one of the big carriers: Verizon, AT&T or T-Mobile. With their plans ranging from $60 to $200 a month for individuals and families, the price of a phone is soon eclipsed by the recurring service bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Citi Bike Service Is Worse in Low-Income Neighborhoods, Study Finds
description: The report found that the problems are worst in neighborhoods that are largely populated by Black, Latino and low-income residents on the outer edges of the city.
content: Citi Bike riders in New York City are getting bad service, and the problem is worse in low-income neighborhoods, the city comptroller said in a report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dickson
title: Martians, Dolls and a Cellist’s Dog: The Many Worlds of Jennifer Walshe
description: The Irish composer blends everyday items with Dada-like theatricals. But there’s a serious purpose to her explorations.
content: A few weeks ago, Jennifer Walshe was backstage at a concert hall in Essen, Germany, searching for the exit when she paused near the green room. A double bass bow was laid out, ready for the evening’s performance; attached to it, wobbling in the air, were several black-and-white balloons. Walshe grinned and pulled out her phone to snap a picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Chai
title: What’s Your Favorite Movie to Watch at the Holidays? We Want to Know.
description: We’re asking readers to share the movies they turn to every year as part of a holiday tradition.
content: When I was growing up, the holidays meant no school, which gave me the chance to curl up on the couch in a robe and fuzzy socks while drinking hot chocolate from a red thermos. Everyone gathered at home, and if we were lucky, there was snow falling outside, and we’d usually have one movie playing: “A Christmas Story.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Charlie Savage
title: How Trump and His Allies Plan to Wield Power in 2025
description: Donald J. Trump and his allies are already laying the groundwork for a possible second Trump presidency, forging plans for an even more extreme agenda than his first term.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump declared in the first rally of his 2024 presidential campaign: “I am your retribution.” He later vowed to use the Justice Department to go after his political adversaries, starting with President Biden and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: More Migrants on Terrorism Watch List Crossed U.S. Border
description: The numbers are a minuscule percentage of the total arrested after crossing the border, officials said.
content: An increasing number of migrants arrested at the southern border over the past year are on the United States’ terrorist watch list, according to government data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Joe Sharkey, Travel Writer Who Survived Midair Collision, Dies at 77
description: He offered advice to business travelers in hundreds of columns in The Times. His eyewitness account of a disaster was front-page news.
content: Joe Sharkey, who delivered pragmatic advice to business travelers in hundreds of columns in The New York Times only to find himself at the focal point of a harrowing disaster in 2006, when the executive jet in which he was flying collided with a Boeing 737 over Brazil, died on Nov. 6 at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Mahler, James B. Stewart and Benjamin Mullin
title: How David Zaslav Blew Up Hollywood
description: A merger put him in the driver’s seat at Warner Brothers, one of the industry’s biggest studios. It has been a wild ride.
content: It was April 2022, and David Zaslav had just closed the deal of a lifetime. From the helm of his relatively small and unglamorous cable company, Discovery, he had taken control of a sprawling entertainment conglomerate that included perhaps the most storied movie studio on the planet, Warner Brothers. The longtime New Yorker had always loved movies, and against the advice of several media peers, he had moved to Hollywood and taken over Jack Warner’s historic office, hauling the old mogul’s desk out of storage and topping it off with an old-time handset telephone. So far things were going great. He had met all the stars and players, was widely feted as the next in line to save the eternally struggling industry and was well into the process of renovating a landmark house in Beverly Hills. “You’re the dog that caught the bus,” the billionaire octogenarian cable pioneer John Malone, one of Discovery’s largest shareholders, told him. All he needed to do now was pay back the $56 billion in debt that he piled onto the new company to make the deal happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: Ballantine House Overhaul to ‘Wake It Up and Shake It Up’
description: The renovated Gilded Age mansion of beer makers in Newark is filled with surprises: a Black history from the 19th century that has been largely invisible.
content: Sumptuous gilded ornamentation still teems throughout the brick home of the Ballantine family of beer makers in Newark, built in 1885. But objects and artworks newly incorporated into the period rooms show how underappreciated strivers maneuvered in Newark society during the Ballantines’ heyday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Lawyers Call for Mistrial in Civil Fraud Case, Attacking Judge
description: The long-shot effort doubled as a political salvo against the judge, Arthur F. Engoron, who is expected to reject it.
content: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump on Wednesday called for a mistrial in the civil fraud case against him in New York, arguing that the judge and his law clerk were politically biased against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Steven Lee Myers
title: Antisemitic and Anti-Muslim Hate Speech Surges Across the Internet
description: Fueled by the conflict between Israel and Gaza and stoked by extremists, hate speech has spiked on social media platforms such as X, Facebook and Instagram, researchers said.
content: On Oct. 7, the day Hamas attacked Israel, the hashtag #HitlerWasRight appeared on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter. Over the next month, more than 46,000 posts featured the hashtag, often alongside language that called for violence against Jews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samar Abu Elouf
title: What One Photo Shows About a Gaza Hospital in Chaos
description: A single photograph captures the horror of a hospital in Gaza that is running out of everything but patients.
content: “Red!” “Yellow!” “Green!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: What a U.S.-China Climate Deal Means for COP28
description: It could deliver a jolt of ambition ahead of the global talks.
content: The United States and China announced an agreement on Tuesday evening to sharply increase clean energy, displace fossil fuels and reduce the emissions that are warming the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: In His First Big Showdown, an Unyielding Conservative Yields
description: Speaker Mike Johnson chose avoiding a shutdown over a fiscal confrontation that Representative Mike Johnson might have welcomed.
content: Just weeks into his new job, Speaker Mike Johnson has already learned a valuable, if painful, lesson: Being an uncompromising conservative hard-liner is much easier from the backbenches of the House than it is from the leadership suites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Life Is Raw. Life Is a Work of Art. Enter the World of Ivo Dimchev.
description: The acclaimed performance artist, choreographer, singer and now New York City resident presents the interactive “In Hell With Jesus/Top 40” at La MaMa.
content: Ivo Dimchev, a queer performance artist from Bulgaria whose brash charm has been known to compel people to take their clothes off and join him onstage — it happened at Joe’s Pub last month — has questions. And more questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Eileen Sullivan
title: F.B.I. Ramps Up Investigations of Hamas
description: Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, made the disclosure in testifying about threats to the United States after Hamas’s surprise attack on southern Israel last month.
content: Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, said on Wednesday that the bureau had opened a slew of investigations into Hamas as it tries to thwart potential attacks and stymie financial support for the militant group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Another Republican Joins Alaska Race Seeking to Oust Peltola
description: Lt. Gov. Nancy Dahlstrom is challenging Mary Peltola, who scored upset wins last year against Sarah Palin to flip Alaska’s sole seat in the House to the Democrats for the first time in 50 years.
content: A second Republican has joined the race in Alaska to challenge Representative Mary S. Peltola, a popular Democrat who holds the state’s sole House seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Cannot Shift Covid Funds to Climate Projects, Court Rules
description: The decision could rip a hole in Berlin’s budget and complicate the transition to a greener economy.
content: Germany’s highest court ruled on Wednesday that the government’s plan to repurpose tens of billions of euros from a pandemic fund to help finance environmental projects violated the nation’s Constitution. The decision threatens to rip a hole in the country’s budget and complicate its transition to a greener economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What I’m Reading
description: A history of forced population transfers sheds light on present conflicts.
content: When I’m trying to get my head around a topic, I often like to approach it somewhat diagonally: reading not just about the thing in question, but also about similar problems that have come up around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why a Boston Tea Party Patriot Is Being Honored in Brooklyn
description: Ebenezer Stevens was among those who boarded three British ships in a symbolic act that helped jump-start the American Revolution.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out why a grave in Brooklyn is getting a plaque about the Boston Tea Party. We’ll also find out about a new theater at the site of what is widely considered the first Black theater company in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Fact-Checking Haley and DeSantis in Their Race to Rival Trump
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, have attacked each other with misleading claims on dealings with Chinese companies, energy and refugees.
content: Nikki Haley, a former governor of South Carolina, and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida are vying to dethrone the Republican Party’s clear presidential front-runner, Donald J. Trump. But first one needs to triumph over the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Matthew Rosenberg
title: Israel and Hamas Appear to Be Near Hostage Deal, Officials Say
description: Under the proposed agreement, Hamas would release 50 women and children abducted during the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks for roughly the same number of Palestinian women and children held in Israeli prisons.
content: Israel believes that Wednesday’s raid on Al-Shifa Hospital will put pressure on Hamas to finish a deal to trade dozens of Israeli captives for Palestinian prisoners, according to two senior Israeli officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Imagining Worlds That Don’t Exist
description: The stage designer and artist Es Devlin brings decades of work to life in an experiential monograph and exhibition at the Cooper Hewitt in New York.
content: Es Devlin is a British designer of memories and psychologies, ideas and dreams. She has created environments for operas, dance works and plays (her scenic design for “The Lehman Trilogy” won the Tony); designed concert tours for Beyoncé, U2, Kanye West, Adele and Miley Cyrus; worked on the opening ceremony of the Rio de Janeiro Olympic Games and the closing ceremony of the London Olympic Games; imagined fashion shows for Louis Vuitton; and invented huge installations, centered around endangered species and endangered languages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I’m Estranged From My Best Friend but Still Invited to Her Family Holidays. Help!
description: A reader feels conflicted about attending celebrations as a friend of the family when the woman who was her original connection won’t be there. Should she bow out?
content: My friend and I have been BFFs for over 40 years — since sixth grade. I spend most holidays with her family. I love being with them! The problem: Our friendship has taken a bad turn, and I’m sure that I’m the reason she’s been skipping family holidays lately. After her divorce, she jumped into internet dating. She seems to relish the trolling and catfishing online. She swears off the apps, then tells me about another terrible experience a month later. Finally, I noted that the apps seem to be an endless, negative cycle in her life. She lashed out at me for not being supportive. So, I told her to drive someone else crazy with her love life. That was two years ago, and we haven’t spoken since. I suggested to her family they tell her I won’t be coming to holidays anymore, so they can all be together again. But her family wants me there. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and David E. Sanger
title: Biden and Xi Meet at a Backdrop for Hollywood and Tech-Titan Weddings
description: The meeting took place at a giant 20th-century estate built by a family that made its fortune in the gold rush.
content: Filoli, a grand house and garden on 654 acres of rolling green grounds near the California coast, has been a supporting character in the 1980s television drama “Dynasty” and the 2001 romantic comedy “The Wedding Planner.” It has been the venue for top-dollar nuptials of Facebook executives, and the public can tour the gardens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moshe Emilio Lavi
title: The Hostages Are Not a Diversion From This War. They’re at the Heart of It.
description: We will not rest until all the captives taken on Oct. 7 are freed.
content: More than five weeks ago, on Oct. 7, my brother-in-law Omri Miran was yanked away from his wife, my sister Lishay, and their two beautiful daughters, Roni and Alma, and kidnapped from his home in Kibbutz Nahal Oz. The four of them had been held captive together at gunpoint by Hamas terrorists and their accomplices for hours; the family witnessed their community burn and their neighbors executed. And then they were separated: Omri was taken captive to the Gaza Strip, and Lishay, Roni and Alma were left behind, waiting for a similar fate or worse before Israel Defense Forces soldiers eventually rescued them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Luke Broadwater
title: House Ethics Panel Will Not Push to Expel George Santos
description: A lengthy investigation of Representative George Santos will conclude this week, but the panel leaves his fate in the hands of his fellow House members.
content: The House Ethics Committee will not call for Representative George Santos’s expulsion as a result of its nearly nine-month investigation, the panel’s chair, Representative Michael Guest, said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Manchester City’s $500 Million Payroll Is Largest in English Soccer History
description: The club, which dominates the Premier League, is backed by seemingly limitless cash from its Emirati owner, Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed al Nahyan.
content: Manchester City, the Premier League’s dominant team for much of the past decade, announced on Wednesday that it had spent more on player salaries last season than any team in British soccer history, paying out more than $500 million as it claimed English and European championships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Welcome to the New Economics of Tipping
description: Changes in technology and custom have shifted the balance of power away from customers.
content: Why do you tip? And have your reasons for tipping changed lately? Is there less gratitude in the mix and more — shall we say — fear?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Butler
title: ‘Translating’ a Times Article to Reach New Audiences
description: College freshmen read a New York Times Magazine piece about issues in education, then communicate what they learned by experimenting with audience and format.
content: This teaching idea comes from Megan Butler, a doctoral candidate at the University of Washington who teaches composition in the Program in Writing and Rhetoric at U.W. She also teaches English to refugees and new immigrants in Seattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
title: Is Argentina the First A.I. Election?
description: The two men jostling to be the country’s next president are using artificial intelligence to create images and videos to promote themselves and attack each other.
content: The posters dotting the streets of Buenos Aires had a certain Soviet flare to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Could Remote Work Be a New ‘Mommy Track’?
description: A conversation with Sarah Kessler, a reporter who wrote about how work-from-home norms may make it harder for women to get ahead.
content: In what has been called a silver lining to the pandemic, the share of women who are in the labor force has reached an all-time high, in part because of the increased flexibility that came with remote work, which has allowed mothers to more easily juggle professional and child care responsibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah E. Elia
title: Four Ways to Engage Multilingual Learners With The Times
description: A teacher of both English as a New Language and World Languages suggests ideas for bringing a global perspective to the news.
content: This teaching idea was submitted by Sarah E. Elia, a teacher at Saugerties Central School District in Saugerties, N.Y., and a past president of New York State Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Where Does Religion Come From?
description: How do you get from the desire for meaning or the fear of death to the specific content of religious belief?
content: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, an ex-Muslim critic of Islamic fundamentalism and longtime champion of Enlightenment liberalism, has announced that she now calls herself a Christian — a conversion that she attributes to a twofold realization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: He Carried the Bags (and the Secrets) for the Beatles
description: A new biography resuscitates the colorful, tragic life of Mal Evans: roadie, confidant, procurer, cowbell player.
content: He was a “gentle giant.” A “teddy bear” who once posed with a koala. A “lovable, cuddly guy.” Of all the people in the Beatles’ entourage, Mal Evans was indisputably the most Muppet-like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Can’t Deport Asylum Seekers to Rwanda, Supreme Court Rules
description: Dealing a major blow to the governing Conservative Party, Britain’s highest court said the East African country was not a safe place for refugees.
content: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a policy to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda is unlawful, dealing a major blow to a Conservative government that has long described the plan as central to its pledge to stop the arrival of the small boats that cross the English Channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Gwyneth Paltrow’s Ski Trial Is Getting the Musical Treatment
description: Is there nothing that can’t be put to song? A small London theater production about the much-covered trial will ask the audience to be jury members.
content: It’s not your average Christmas love story. But here goes: “She’s the Goop-founding, door-sliding, Shakespeare-in-loving, consciously-uncoupling Hollywood superstar. He’s a retired optometrist from Utah. In 2016, they went skiing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: These Books Will Make Your Relationship Stronger
description: We asked 14 psychologists, counselors and therapists for the titles they recommend to couples.
content: There’s evidence that strong relationships are central to our happiness and well being. But getting along with others is complicated, and maintaining healthy romantic partnerships in particular can be challenging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M.’s Contract Deal With U.A.W. Faces Surprisingly Stiff Opposition
description: Many longstanding General Motors workers have been voting against the tentative accord, which they feel insufficiently improves retirement benefits.
content: A United Automobile Workers union vote on a tentative contract agreement with General Motors that provides record wage increases has run into unexpectedly strong resistance from veteran workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Downey
title: Adventures on Dublin’s Culinary Trail
description: Local ingredients and new takes on traditional dishes figure prominently on menus created by younger generations of local chefs and restaurateurs, as well as foreign chefs who have made the Irish capital their home.
content: The Irish have helped perfect, perhaps even invent, the pub as we know it. Storied Dublin locales like Gravediggers and Mulligans keep that tradition alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘David Holmes: The Boy Who Lived’ Review: Harry Potter’s Stunt Wizard
description: A documentary looks at the friendship that formed during the Harry Potter movies between Daniel Radcliffe and his main stunt double, who was seriously injured in 2009.
content: Viewers of the eight Harry Potter features may never have considered the bonds that formed over the decade required to make them. “David Holmes: The Boy Who Lived” revolves around the friendship between Daniel Radcliffe, who played Harry, and Holmes, who served as his stunt double for most of those years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Tammy Murphy, N.J.’s First Lady, Enters Crowded Race for Menendez’s Seat
description: Ms. Murphy is likely to face at least three Democratic primary challengers — and possibly Senator Bob Menendez, who is accused of accepting bribes.
content: Tammy Murphy, the wife of Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey, announced on Wednesday that she was running as a Democrat for the U.S. Senate seat now held by the state’s embattled senior senator, Robert Menendez, who has been charged with accepting bribes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: French Judges Issue Warrant for Assad in Syria War Crimes Case
description: The warrant relates to the deadly use of chemical weapons and is a major step to hold President Bashar al-Assad accountable for some of the worst atrocities in Syria’s long conflict.
content: French investigative judges have issued an international arrest warrant for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria that accuses him of complicity in war crimes and crimes against humanity over the deadly use of chemical weapons against his own people, a judicial official said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Life of Milton Friedman Seeks the Nuance in His Free-Market Gospel
description: The new book by Jennifer Burns aims to bring fresh complexity to our understanding of the Nobel Prize-winning economist.
content: In writing her new biography of the Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman, known throughout his long life for his cheerful endorsement of deregulation and free markets, Jennifer Burns certainly had her work cut out for her. Reflecting on how controversial her subject was, she says that one of her goals was “to restore the fullness of Friedman’s thought to his public image.” She depicts Friedman, who died in 2006 at 94, as a victim of a “bipartisan assault,” besieged by radicals on the left and populists on the right who decry the “neoliberalism” that he so ardently promoted. “As he increasingly came to symbolize a political movement,” she writes, “the nuance and complexity of his ideas was lost.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Inside Man: How FIFA Guided the World Cup to Saudi Arabia
description: FIFA’s president, Gianni Infantino, cheered a plan to take soccer’s richest event to the kingdom. He has said little about his years of work to make that happen.
content: As the world reeled from the coronavirus crisis in the fall of 2020, the president of soccer’s global governing body, Gianni Infantino, headed to Rome for an audience with Italy’s prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Afif Amireh
title: Palestinian and Israeli Teens Swam in the Same Pool. Then Came Oct. 7.
description: The teenagers in the Greater Jerusalem swim club made a point of not focusing on their differences. That changed with the war.
content: The rule was unspoken, but the Israeli and Palestinian teenagers in the Greater Jerusalem swim club had abided by it forever without even thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason M. Bailey
title: Debussy and Final Fantasy Are Peers on This Radio Stream
description: Arcade, a new project by Classical California, aims to dispel preconceptions about classical music and video game soundtracks.
content: A treacherous puzzle that lies near the end of Myst, the 1993 point-and-click video game, involves a pipe organ and a spaceship.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 15, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 15, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: For Latin Grammy Nominee Edgar Barrera, Mistakes Can Be Perfection
description: Nominated for 13 awards on Thursday, the producer and songwriter is bringing an organic sound back to Latin pop.
content: At his home and studio in Miami, the Mexican American songwriter and producer Edgar Barrera doesn’t flaunt his 18 Latin Grammy Awards, or the Grammy he won in 2015, or the plaques for his dozens of gold and platinum singles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Our 27 Most Popular Thanksgiving Desserts
description: Caramel apple crisp, tall and creamy cheesecake and a showstopping crimson cranberry curd tart.
content: I know I’m not the only one who feels that the real star of Thanksgiving is dessert. Actually, make that desserts, because chances are there’ll be more than one sweet item gracing your table; maybe pies and ice cream, possibly rounded out with cheesecake, cookies, pudding and so on. On Thanksgiving, over the top is barely enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: It Goes On and On
description: Gary Larson sharpens his endgame.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: We All Love ‘Anne of Green Gables.’ What About ‘Emily of New Moon’?
description: L.M. Montgomery’s oft-forgotten novel, which turns 100 this year, is more timely than ever.
content: Carrots. Puffed sleeves. Scrapes. Liniment. Kindred spirits. Bosom friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rafaela Bassili
title: Sofia Coppola’s Subversive Search for Truth in ‘Priscilla’
description: Hollywood is addicted to mythologizing biopics. ‘‘Priscilla’’ offers something different.
content: As with much of her other work, the opening of Sofia Coppola’s latest film, “Priscilla,” is all about textures. A pair of manicured feet sink into a shag carpet; a fingernail is carefully polished in red; we see the back of a prodigious black bouffant, then the dexterous painting of a dramatic cat eye with black liner. Priscilla Presley (Cailee Spaeny) paces around Graceland relentlessly. There’s nothing for her to do, and too much for her to process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
title: Wary Kyiv Residents Rediscover the Joys of a Good Night’s Sleep
description: An unusually long lull in Russian bombing has left people in the Ukrainian capital feeling well-rested, healthier and more productive, at least for now.
content: For month after endless month, nights in Kyiv were punctuated by the wail of air raid sirens and the sound of explosions from missile and drone attacks. Now, an unusually long lull in nighttime bombardments of the city by Russian forces is allowing residents to do something they have been dreaming of — finally getting some sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Strangler’ Review: All the Pretty, Pitied Corpses
description: This strange, seductive film from 1970, directed by Paul Vecchiali, borrows the conventions of the serial-killer thriller and turns them inside out.
content: Originally released in France in 1970, and now available in a new restoration, “The Strangler” is a strange, seductive film that takes the conventions of the serial-killer thriller and explodes them with baroque colors and convulsive camera movements. It’s like “Peeping Tom” meets one of Dario Argento’s giallo joints, but slathered in a coat of melancholic malaise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: New York Attorney General Sues Pepsi Over Plastic Packaging
description: Letitia James claimed that the snack giant was the largest contributor to pollution along the Buffalo River, which a state survey found was contaminated with single-use plastic products.
content: The New York attorney general sued PepsiCo on Wednesday, accusing the food and beverage giant of endangering the environment and misleading the public about its goals to eliminate single-use plastic in its packaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The New Hampshire Primary Will Be Jan. 23
description: The date, announced by state officials, defies the Democratic National Committee’s decision to have South Carolina vote first.
content: New Hampshire’s presidential primary will be held Jan. 23, state officials announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Liberal Agenda of the 1960s Has Reached a Fork in the Road
description: Overturning Roe changed politics. Overturning affirmative action did not.
content: What do the strikingly different public responses to two recent Supreme Court rulings — one on abortion, the other on affirmative action — suggest about the prospects for the liberal agenda?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler and Michael J. de la Merced
title: The Inflation Rally Goes Global
description: A better-than-expected Consumer Price Index report triggered a big surge in stocks and bonds, as investors bet that interest rates will begin to fall.
content: Yesterday’s impressive rally in U.S. stocks and bonds has gone worldwide this morning, as investors see central banks making gains in their fight against inflation. Adding to the good news was a breakthrough in the House last night that could avert a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: With Covid, Is It Really Possible to Say We Went Too Far?
description: I spoke with Bethany McLean and Joe Nocera about their alternate take on what America did.
content: In 2020, many Americans told themselves that all it would take to halt the pandemic was replacing the president and hitting the “science button.” In 2023, it looks like we’re telling ourselves the opposite: that if we were given the chance to run the pandemic again, it would have been better just to hit “abort” and give up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: How to Salvage Your Day After a Bad Night’s Sleep
description: You’ll need to adjust for your shortcomings (and take a well-timed nap).
content: Most of us know that good sleep is a pillar of good health, on par with exercise and nutrition. And yet most of us have had a night (or many nights) when it all went sideways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Up to 10 Inches of Rain Expected in Southeastern Florida
description: Millions in the Miami metro area were at risk of seeing excessive rainfall Wednesday into Thursday. It could lead to flash flooding.
content: A confluence of storm systems developing in the Gulf of Mexico and off the east coast of Florida was set to drive a consistent pattern of heavy rainfall in the Miami area Wednesday into Thursday, which could lead to flash flooding, potentially exacerbated by the high tides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Lauren Hirsch
title: Rory McIlroy Resigns From PGA Tour Board
description: The decision came about five months after the tour struck an agreement with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund to create a joint company.
content: Rory McIlroy, the esteemed golfer who was among the most outspoken opponents of his sport’s swelling ties to Saudi Arabia, has resigned from the PGA Tour’s board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liset Cruz and Claire Fahy
title: Columbia Faces Protests After Suspending 2 Pro-Palestinian Groups
description: Students rallied after the university barred two groups from holding campus events until the end of the semester, and faculty members walked out in protest.
content: As police officers guarded the wrought iron gates protecting Columbia University’s main campus on Tuesday evening, checking for student identification cards, a group gathered around a stone sundial at the center of the quad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: A Czech Reporter Saw San Francisco’s Highlights. Then He Was Robbed.
description: The city cleaned up its streets and added police officers, but one ugly incident disrupted the planned narrative. Residents have tried to make up for it with an outpouring of compassion.
content: Bohumil Vostal, a correspondent for a Czech public television station, spent Sunday reporting on the best parts of San Francisco. He toured an art gallery, visited Chinatown and even hired a guide with a vintage Volkswagen bus to drive him to the Golden Gate Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Absolute Chaos’: Residents Evacuated From Public Housing Tower in England
description: The evacuation of a tower block in Bristol, after surveys found structural concerns, drew fresh attention to the construction of Britain’s public housing high-rises and possible safety issues.
content: Shaban Ali has lived in a public housing tower in Bristol, in southwest England, for seven years. On Tuesday, the plan was to stay in: dinner, a bath and watching “Paddington” with his two young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. Inflation Slows to 4.6%, Lowest in Two Years
description: Inflation is expected to continue to slow, but central bank officials have said they will keep interest rates high.
content: Inflation in Britain slowed last month, bringing the rate to its lowest level in two years, in a welcome easing of stubborn price pressures. Consumer prices rose 4.6 percent in October from a year earlier, the Office for National Statistics said on Wednesday, down from 6.7 percent in the previous month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: As Leaders Meet, Musicians from Philadelphia Orchestra Tour China
description: The visit, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the orchestra’s pathbreaking 1973 visit to Beijing, drew praise from President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China.
content: President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, face a host of thorny geopolitical issues as they meet Wednesday in San Francisco: trade, Taiwan and the war between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Saffitz
title: A Stunning (but Not Stressful) Thanksgiving Menu That Lets You Enjoy the Day
description: These pared-down recipes from the cookbook author Claire Saffitz are just what you need.
content: After roughly a decade of cooking Thanksgiving for my family, I’ve arrived at one simple truth: The more effort I put forward, the less I enjoy the meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle MacNeill
title: McDonald’s Growing Appetite for Fashion
description: By working with Vetements, the skate brand Palace and now Crocs, the fast-food chain has become an unlikely source of style.
content: Jeremy Scott had just started interviewing for the job of creative director at Moschino when he had an epiphany of sorts while driving through Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: For an N.B.A. Star, a Dream House Became a Nightmare
description: Irate investors looking for a bankrupt “crypto king” were regular visitors to the new Toronto-area home of Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder.
content: The six bedroom, 10,000 square-foot house on Lake Ontario that Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, a star player with the Oklahoma City Thunder, bought for just over 8.4 million Canadian dollars, or $6.1 million, should have been a dream home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kabir Chibber
title: Did ‘Demolition Man’ Predict the Millennial?
description: A cult classic saw the future — kind of.
content: Now that we live in the future, we no longer seem to make as many films about the future — at least not the way we once did, when we tried our hardest to imagine a future as different from the present as we were from ancient history. Today, with all of human knowledge in our pockets, we prefer to think in terms of alternate timelines, paths not taken, the multiverse of infinite possibilities. We’re looking sideways, not forward. But for most of the existence of cinema, a glorious near-centennial from “Metropolis” (1927) to, let’s say, “WALL-E” (2008), people used celluloid to dream of what lay ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Storms, Rising Seas and Salty Drinking Water Threaten Lower Louisiana
description: Where the Mississippi River ends, the compounding threats of drought and climate change put pressure on communities that feel forgotten.
content: First, the flowers and vegetables in Cherie Pete’s backyard in Venice, La., began to die. Then she had to take sweet tea off the menu at her roadside snack shop as saltwater coursed out of her faucets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Staffing and Technology Woes Threaten Aviation Safety, Report Says
description: The Federal Aviation Administration turned to outside experts after a string of near collisions. They called for addressing the shortage of air traffic controllers and improving aging tech.
content: A group of outside experts appointed by the Federal Aviation Administration called on Wednesday for “urgent action” to address safety risks in the nation’s aviation system, highlighting issues like staffing shortages among air traffic controllers and outdated technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: At 98, She’s a Social Media Star
description: Dorothy Wiggins needed a hobby after the death of her husband. Now she’s big on TikTok and Instagram.
content: On a recent evening in the West Village of Manhattan, Dorothy Wiggins, a petite 98-year-old woman wearing a dark coat and a pink scarf, left her townhouse to check out Little Ruby’s Cafe, a chic new restaurant in her neighborhood. Inside, she approached the hostess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: An Israeli raid on Al-Shifa Hospital.
content: The Israeli military said early this morning that its troops were raiding Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital, a complex of buildings where thousands of people have sheltered and conditions for patients have grown increasingly grim as supplies have dwindled. Fighting has been raging nearby for days, and the hospital was struck at least four times over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: By the Numbers: How Schools Struggled During the Pandemic
description: New federal data from the 2020-2021 school year shows the reach of online learning, the struggle to hire teachers and the lack of counselors.
content: The federal Education Department released a new trove of data on Wednesday from the 2020-21 school year, the first full academic year during the coronavirus pandemic. It adds to the understanding of how the education system responded to Covid-19, and demonstrates how many schools struggled to handle the cascade of challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Ann Fennelly
title: Stop Corporatizing My Students
description: Equating successful education with successful business is changing not only what gets taught but whom.
content: I have taught creative writing at Mississippi’s flagship university for over 20 years, and I’ve witnessed a powerful outcome: Students who master written and spoken communication can change the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: ‘Erase Gaza’: War Unleashes Incendiary Rhetoric in Israel
description: Experts say that inflammatory statements by prominent Israelis are normalizing ideas like the killing of civilians and mass deportations.
content: Shock, grief and pain have cascaded across Israel since Hamas gunmen poured out of Gaza to kill an estimated 1,200 Israeli civilians and soldiers on Oct. 7. So have anger and a thirst for vengeance, which the country’s leaders are verbalizing in language that critics in Israel say often crosses the line into incitement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: V.A. Recruits Millionth Veteran for Its Genetic Research Database
description: Diverse data from the Million Veteran Program has already contributed to hundreds of medical studies, and the V.A. is continuing to recruit more participants.
content: On Saturday, after a 12-year effort, the Department of Veterans Affairs reached a long-term goal — it enrolled the millionth veteran in a genetic database, the Million Veteran Program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
title: U.S. Presses China to Stop Flow of Fentanyl
description: President Biden put pressure on Xi Jinping to crack down on the Chinese facilities that make chemical compounds used in potent drugs.
content: President Biden pressed the Chinese leader Xi Jinping on Wednesday to crack down on the Chinese firms that are helping to produce fentanyl, a potent drug that has killed hundreds of thousands of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Michael Podhorzer
description: The Nov. 14, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Michael Podhorzer. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Supreme Court’s New Ethics Code: ‘Worthless’
description: Readers criticize the code as weak and unenforceable. Also: The Trump trial; an optional Regents exam in New York; Anne Frank; vaping among the young.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Learned I Fathered a Daughter. Should I Contact Her, Against My Ex’s Wishes?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the burden of keeping destabilizing secrets.
content: Twenty-five years ago, I unknowingly impregnated a girlfriend. We broke up soon after she conceived, and she moved away without telling me she was pregnant. She married, and brought her daughter up to believe that her husband was the biological father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Kroll
title: The Filmmaker and the Superspy
description: In “A Woman I Know,” Mary Haverstick discovers that the subject of her documentary may have once been a key player in Cold War espionage.
content: Near the beginning of her new book, Mary Haverstick quotes James Angleton, the head of the C.I.A.’s counterintelligence division during the Cold War. Angleton described the world of spycraft as a “wilderness of mirrors,” where no one could be trusted and nothing was quite what it seemed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: She Broke Barriers in Music. But She’s Uneasy About the Attention.
description: A new documentary tells the story of Orin O’Brien, a double bassist who became the only woman in the New York Philharmonic when she joined in 1966 and helped open doors for others.
content: For decades, the New York Philharmonic, the oldest symphony orchestra in the United States, was an all-male bastion. Then, in 1966, came Orin O’Brien, who played the double bass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Local Valley’ and More
description: I’m a national correspondent for The New York Times based in St. Paul, Minn. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.
content: I’m a national correspondent for The New York Times based in St. Paul, Minn. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.

title: Wirecutter’s Most Popular Gifts
description: Every year, a few gifts rise to the top.
content: Every year, a few gifts rise to the top.

author: By Judith Surber
title: Addiction Ravaged My Family and Tribe. I’m Fighting to Get Them Back.

author: By Gazan Ministry of Health
title: Babies at Al-Shifa Hospital Moved to Ward With Electricity
description: Video released by Gaza’s Health Ministry shows more than a dozen newborn babies being transferred to patient beds at Al-Shifa hospital, after the hospital’s incubators lost power.
content: Video released by Gaza’s Health Ministry shows more than a dozen newborn babies being transferred to patient beds at Al-Shifa hospital, after the hospital’s incubators lost power.

author: By The New York Times
title: Both Biden and Xi Want to Avoid Conflict Between the U.S. and China
description: President Xi Jinping of China told President Biden that “turning their backs on each other is not an option” for the two superpowers.
content: President Xi Jinping of China told President Biden that “turning their backs on each other is not an option” for the two superpowers.
